column4: Can someone take a moment to explain what packages I need to collect POP3 mail from my ISP, store in on my Ubuntu server, and be able to access it by IMAP anywhere on my home LAN?
fetchmail to get the mail, courier-imap to server them up
Does Dovecot offer any advantages over courier-imap?
actually, now that you mention it, i'm using dovecot, not courier
I want the easiest to setup, I spend an age to get dovecot working (its now sorta working).   How does sending mail fit into the scheme of things?  in a setup like this?
I suppose what I am not saying, is I will never be opening or sending emails from the Ubuntu system directly, it will always be an intermediary
if you're not going to send mail from this box then you don't really need to install sendmail, postfix, etc.
However I DO want the mails to live in a IMAP "sent" folder.
so I think I do need to send them via the ubuntu system.  I'm not sure how it all connects together tho!
i would be surprised if there are not several how-to's out there with step-by-step instructions.
I have looked and not come up with much in the way of howtos, or they are just not the right setup
I thought my requirements here would not be too out of the ordinary.
basically i pop mail down from a server and serve it out via imap at home, just like you want to.  but i send my mail through gmail and sent mail doesn't get saved on my local server.
so i'm not really sure how that would hook in there either.  :-)
I thought it was just me being a thicky!!!
i guess you would just setup postfix and configure it to use the same maildir that dovecot does
markg: then have postfix forward to the server you pop mail from
are postfix and sendmail similar applications?  Do they serve the same general purpose?
yes, there are quite a few mail transfer agents (MTAs)

so I need fetchmail to collect POP3 mail from the remote ISP deliver it to my ubuntu mailbox, then dovecot to serve it up, and I need sendmail to send it out again to my ISP's SMTP server.  Is that the nuts of it?
yup, that should do it.
